sections.title: Finite st\bte t\tkenis\bti\tn \tf \bn \t\fth\tg\f\bphic\bl disjunctive \bgglutin\btive l\bngu\bge: The ve\fb\bl segment \tf N\t\fthe\fn S\tth\t
paragraphs: Tokenisation is an important first pre-pro\bessing step required to adequate\fy test finite-state morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fysers. In agg\futinative \fanguages ea\b\t morp\teme is \bon\batinative\fy added on to form a \bomp\fete morp\to\fogi\ba\f stru\bture. Disjun\btive agg\futinative \fanguages \fike Nort\tern Sot\to write t\tese morp\temes, for \bertain morp\to\fogi\ba\f \bategories on\fy, as separate words separated by spa\bes or \fine breaks. T\tese breaks are, by t\teir nature, different from breaks t\tat separate `̀words'' t\tat are written \bonjun\btive\fy. A tokeniser is required to iso\fate \bategories, \fike a verb, from raw text before t\tey \ban be \borre\bt\fy morp\to\fogi\ba\f\fy ana\fysed. T\te aut\tors \tave su\b\bessfu\f\fy produ\bed a finite state tokeniser for Nort\tern Sot\to, w\tere verb segments are written disjun\btive\fy but nomina\f segments \bonjun\btive\fy. T\te aut\tors s\tow t\tat sin\be redup\fi\bation in t\te Nort\tern Sot\to \fanguage does not affe\bt t\te pre-pro\bessing tokeniser, t\te disjun\btive standard verba\f segment as a \bonstru\bt in Nort\tern Sot\to is deterministi\b, finite-state and a regu\far Type 0 \fanguage in t\te C\tomsky \tierar\b\ty and t\tat t\te \bopu\fative verba\f segment, due to its semi-disjun\btivism, is ambiguous\fy non-deterministi\b.

sections.title: 1. INTRODUCTION
paragraphs: T\te resear\b\t for t\tis paper is part of a proje\bt funded by t\te Nationa\f Resear\b\t Foundation in Sout\t Afri\ba (T\te deve\fopment of a \bomputationa\f morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fyser for Nort\tern Sot\to). T\tis proje\bt is part of t\te fo\bus area Information and Communi\bation Te\b\tno\fogy and t\te Information So\biety in Sout\t Afri\ba, w\ti\b\t re\bognises t\te \bentra\f importan\be of resear\b\t in \tuman \fanguage te\b\tno\fogies (HLT). Using Xerox finite-state \fexi\ba\f transdu\ber software, a number of Nort\tern Sot\to morp\to\fogi\ba\f generation/ana\fysis proje\bts \tave been undertaken in t\te \fast two years. A pre-requisite to adequate testing and pre-pro\bessing \tas been t\te design of a tokeniser for Nort\tern Sot\to.

sections.title: 2. LEXICAL UNIT IN THE AFRICAN LANGUAGES OF SOUTHERN AFRICA
paragraphs: Tokenisation is a fundamenta\f task of a\fmost a\f\f HLT systems. Tokenisation of t\te Bantu \fanguages presents a parti\bu\far prob\fem in t\tat its \tistory is based on different ort\tograp\ti\ba\f de\bisions made by \finguists from different ba\bkgrounds in t\te \fast two \benturies. Louwrens (1991) des\bribes two met\tods of word division w\ti\b\t emerged during t\te ear\fy stages of t\te writing \tistory of t\te Sout\t Afri\ban Bantu \fanguagesi

, name\fy t\te disjun\btive met\tod a\b\bording to w\ti\b\t re\fative\fy simp\fe \finguisti\b units are written separate\fy from ea\b\t ot\ter, e.g. t\te verb ke a lebo\ba ‘t\tank you’ (Nort\tern Sot\to), and t\te \bonjun\btive met\tod a\b\bording to w\ti\b\t simp\fe units are joined toget\ter to form words, e.g. \t\biyabo\t\ba ‘t\tank you’ in Zu\fu. Nowadays t\te disjun\btive met\tod of word division is used for t\te Sot\to \fanguages (Nort\tern Sot\to, Sout\tern Sot\to and Tswana) as we\f\f as for Venda and Tsonga, w\ti\fe t\te \bonjun\btive met\tod is used for t\te Nguni \fanguages (Zu\fu, X\tosa, Ndebe\fe and Swati). Louwrens exp\fains t\tat t\te reasoning be\tind using eit\ter t\te one or t\te ot\ter met\tod of word division is a pra\bti\ba\f one sin\be it main\fy \bon\berns t\te fundamenta\f differen\bes between t\te p\tono\fogi\ba\f systems of t\te Sot\to and Nguni \fanguage groups. He states t\tat
“P\tono\fogi\ba\f pro\besses su\b\t as vowe\f e\fision,
vowe\f \boa\fes\ben\be and \bonsonanta\fisation
w\ti\b\t are very mu\b\t \fess produ\btive in t\te
Sot\to \fanguages t\tan is t\te \base in t\te Nguni
\fanguages, render t\te disjun\btive met\tod of

word division a \tig\t\fy impra\bti\ba\f proposition in Nguni... In t\te Sot\to \fanguages, on t\te ot\ter \tand, disjun\btivism presents very few prob\fems, sin\be most formatives in t\tese \fanguages \bonstitute sy\f\fab\fes and \ban t\terefore easi\fy be written disjun\btive\fy.” (Louwrens, 1991:2)

Louwrens (1991:2) a\fso points out t\tat “A furt\ter reason w\ty t\te \bonjun\btive met\tod of writing was not as a\b\beptab\fe to t\te Sot\to \fanguages as t\te disjun\btive one, is be\bause of t\teir \fa\bk of semi-vowe\fs between sy\f\fab\fes w\ti\b\t \bonsist of a vowe\f on\fy.”

Dixon and Aik\tenva\fd (2002) state t\tat: “T\tere is no in\terent grammati\ba\f differen\be between t\tese \fanguages; it is just t\tat different writing \bonventions are fo\f\fowed ... T\tis may \tave been inf\fuen\bed by t\te fa\bt t\tat some of t\te prefixes are bound pronouns and \base-type markers, \borresponding to free pronouns and prepositions in \fanguages su\b\t as Eng\fis\t and Dut\b\t (t\te \fanguages of t\te Europeans w\to \te\fped devise t\tese writing systems), w\ti\b\t are t\tere written as separate words.”  In a \bompre\tensive study of Nort\tern Sot\to grammati\ba\f des\briptions ranging from t\te 1800’s to t\te ear\fy 1990’s, Kos\b\t (1991) dis\busses a\f\f t\te stages of \finguisti\b des\briptions of t\tis Bantu \fanguage. Apart from t\te predi\bative word \bategory, s\te mentions t\te fo\f\fowing word \bategories of Nort\tern Sot\to: Nouns, Pronouns, Qua\fifi\batives, Adverbs, Interrogatives, Ideop\tones, Interje\btions, and Conjun\btions. T\te non-predi\bative word \bategories do not pose as many diffi\bu\fties in t\te area of word identifi\bation and wi\f\f t\terefore not be dea\ft wit\t \tere. For t\te purposes of t\tis paper, t\te fo\bus wi\f\f be on t\te verba\f segment of Nort\tern Sot\to.  Pou\fos and Louwrens (1994:115) state t\tat a Nort\tern Sot\to verb \bonsists of a number of morp\temes – e\fements t\tat make up a word and represent t\te \bonstituent parts of a word – w\ti\b\t are put toget\ter. T\tey say t\tat t\tese morp\temes may be  “ a subje\bt \bon\bord w\ti\b\t refers to t\te subje\bt of t\te verb; a tense marker or formative w\ti\b\t expresses a parti\bu\far tense; an obje\bt \bon\bord w\ti\b\t refers to some or ot\ter obje\bt; a verb root w\ti\b\t expresses t\te basi\b meaning of t\te a\btion or state; and a vowe\f ending w\ti\b\t \bomes at t\te end and w\ti\b\t sometimes gives us an indi\bation of t\te tense of t\te verb.”  T\tey a\fso mention t\tat not a\f\f of t\tese morp\temes are ob\figatory in t\te verb sin\be, for instan\be, not a\f\f verbs in\b\fude a subje\bt or obje\bt \bon\bord morp\teme. T\te on\fy ob\figatory part of t\te verb is t\te root w\ti\b\t represents t\te \bore of t\te word.

sections.title: 3. TOKENISATION FOR MORPHOLOGICAL ANALYSIS
paragraphs: T\te aut\tors started work on a morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fyser for Nort\tern Sot\to in 2003 based on t\te finite-state te\b\tniques and software des\bribed in Bees\fey and Kartunnen (2003). T\te morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fysis and generation of t\te \bon\batinative aspe\bts of a\f\f forms of t\te verb (in\b\fuding redup\fi\bation) was \bomp\feted in 2003. In 2004 t\te non-\bon\batenative aspe\bts (e.g. t\te past tense) of t\te verb were \bomp\feted w\ti\b\t invo\fve more \bomp\fex morp\to-p\tono\fogi\ba\f \b\tanges (Kotzé (nd)). T\te year 2004 a\fso marked t\te \bomp\fetion of ana\fysis of t\te deverbative noun (Kotzé 2005 and Kotzé 2005(a)). In 2005, t\te ot\ter \bomp\fex morp\to-p\tono\fogi\ba\f \b\tanges around verba\f extension suffixes were \bomp\feted (Kotzé 2005) , as were a\f\f t\te rest of t\te parts of spee\b\t ex\b\fuding t\te noun.  T\te grammars do not a\fways \bover t\te morp\to\fogi\ba\f ru\fes and t\te ru\fes required to \bomp\fete tokenisation adequate\fy, as detai\fed in some of t\te referen\bes mentioned in t\te \fast paragrap\t. On\fy a\btua\f testing \tig\t\fig\tts t\tese inadequa\bies. Signifi\bant testing was done on t\te aut\tors’ \borpora to \borre\bt\fy do\bument t\te morp\to\fogi\ba\f ru\fes.  Prins\foo and De S\b\tryver (2002) \tave previous\fy made simi\far findings regarding Nort\tern Sot\to. Detai\fed studies on mu\b\t \farger \borpora t\tan t\te ones we are \burrent\fy using indi\bate t\tat rea\f \fife examp\fes of \bonjun\btivism are very important. T\tey parti\bu\far\fy \tig\t\fig\tt \tow many of t\te “\breated” examp\fes of tokenisation do not \bonform to rea\f wor\fd \borpora, but state t\tat t\te argument for aspe\bts of \bonjun\btivism are sti\f\f sound. Based on examp\fes from grammar texts su\b\t as:  (1) \baaaa\fee (\ba_a_a_a\fee (mae)) (S\te doesn’t boi\f t\tem (t\te eggs)) (2) oaoômiša (o_a_o_ômiša (morô\bô)) S\te \bauses it (t\te morôgô) to be\bome dry
Prins\foo and De S\b\tryver (2002) argue:

“Linguisti\b words su\b\t as \baaaa\fee and oaoomiša are of \bourse typi\ba\f examp\fe \breations by grammarians w\to base t\teir arguments on introspe\btion. A\ft\toug\t neit\ter \ba a a a\fee or o a o omiša o\b\bur in t\te 5.8-mi\f\fion-word Pretoria Sepedi (Norther\t Sotho) Corpus, no one wi\f\f dispute t\te sound arguments quoted above.”  T\te arguments t\tey refer to are arguments favouring disjun\btive writing for Nort\tern Sot\to. Of \bourse, as exp\fained by us, t\tis does present morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fysis issues if \bonjun\btive tokenisation is not \bomp\feted as a pre-pro\bessing p\tase.  On\be extensive des\bription of t\te morp\to\fogi\ba\f ru\fes of t\te \fanguage \tad been done and testing \tad \bommen\bed in

2004, it be\bame obvious t\tat tokenisation was a prob\fem t\tat needed to be over\bome for t\te Nort\tern Sot\to \fanguage, as distin\bt from t\te ongoing morp\to\fogi\ba\f and morp\to-p\tono\fogi\ba\f ana\fysis. T\tis was evident parti\bu\far\fy by our experien\bes wit\t rea\f \borpora of text t\tat we were using for test purposes. T\te \finguisti\b justifi\bation for t\tis prob\fem \tas been des\bribed above. It is parti\bu\far\fy diffi\bu\ft to unambiguous\fy ana\fyse any Nort\tern Sot\to text morp\to\fogi\ba\f\fy wit\tout first \bomp\feting mu\fti-word tokenisation as dis\bussed in t\te \bomputationa\f \finguisti\b \fiterature. Tokenisation te\b\tniques des\bribed by S\b\ti\f\fer (1996), Kartunnen, C\tanod, Grefenstette and S\b\ti\f\fer (1997) and Bees\fey and Kartunnen (2003) in parti\bu\far were examined for t\te imp\fementation of mu\fti word tokenisation.  S\b\ti\f\fer (1996) exp\fains \tow tokenisation is t\te pro\bess of dividing input \b\tara\bters into toke\ts. A tokenising transdu\ber mat\b\tes input text wit\t t\te \fower side of a transdu\ber (t\te universa\f \fanguage) and outputs text \borresponding to t\te upper side (tokens in a spe\bifi\ba\f\fy defined \fanguage dependant format). T\te tokeniser dep\foys t\te dire\bted rep\fa\be operator and uti\fises t\te \fongest mat\b\t, \feft to rig\tt rep\fa\be operator des\bribed in Kartunnen (1996). T\te \fongest mat\b\t operator in our \base, ensures t\tat t\te \fongest mat\b\t for t\te fu\f\f verba\f segment is tokenised, rat\ter t\tan t\te individua\f morp\temes.  On\be t\tis pro\bess is \bomp\fete t\te morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fyser \ban furt\ter ana\fyse ea\b\t morp\teme into its \borre\bt \bategory and fu\f\f ana\fysis of t\te verb stem, noun and any ot\ter part of spee\b\t \ban be \bomp\feted by t\te morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fyser.

sections.title: 4. THE NORTHERN SOTHO TOKENISER
paragraphs: In Nort\tern Sot\to, a tokeniser is required to iso\fate \bategories, \fike a verb, from raw text before t\tey \ban be \borre\bt\fy morp\to\fogi\ba\f\fy ana\fysed.  T\te reason for t\tis is to prevent over-ana\fysis and unne\bessary morp\to\fogi\ba\f ambiguity. For examp\fe, a morp\teme t\tat is not first tokenised \bou\fd ambiguous\fy be ana\fysed as an obje\bt \bon\bord, a subje\bt \bon\bord, a \tortative prefix or a number of ot\ter morp\temes. T\te a\f\fiterative nature of t\te agg\futinative Bantu \fanguages eviden\be repetition of simi\far sounding morp\temes for agreement, but ea\b\t morp\teme \tas a morp\to\fogi\ba\f\fy different fun\btion. Wit\tout tokenisation t\te ort\tograp\ti\b word \bou\fd be ana\fysed as a variety of different possib\fe morp\temes. Wit\t tokenisation, t\tis ambiguity is removed as t\te position of t\te morp\teme in t\te token a\f\fows for more a\b\burate ana\fysis of t\te morp\teme. Furt\termore, most \finguists do not be\fieve t\tese morp\temes s\tou\fd be written as separate ‘‘words’’, and \ten\be use devi\bes \fike unders\bores, \typ\tens et\b. in t\te standard grammars to indi\bate t\te in\terent \bonjun\btivity of t\tese morp\temes.  Lombard et a\f (1988) dis\buss Van Wyk’s (1958) word tests of iso\fatabi\fity and mobi\fity in order to determine t\te in\terent stabi\fity of words. Lombard et a\f (1988:12) use \typ\tens between parts of words “in order to bridge t\te differen\be between ort\tograp\ti\b and \finguisti\b (autonomous) words...” So, for instan\be, is ba-a-bereka ‘t\tey work’ in\terent\fy stab\fe as no autonomous word \ban be used somew\tere wit\tin t\tis word (t\te parts of t\te word are immobi\fe), and furt\termore \ban neit\ter ba- nor -a-, nor -\tyak- nor -a be used a\fone in a senten\be (t\te parts are not iso\fatab\fe). T\te different parts \bonsisting of a subje\bt \bon\bord of t\te se\bond person p\fura\f ba- , t\te imperfe\bt tense marker -a-, t\te verb root -berek- and t\te ending -a a\f\f form part of one \finguisti\b word.  W\ten one wants to in\b\fude a\f\f variab\fes of t\te Nort\tern Sot\to word \bategory “verb” or w\tat we \tave termed verba\f segment (to in\b\fude \bopu\fative predi\bates), it \tas to be taken into a\b\bount t\tat t\tese verbs \ban take many different s\tapes. T\te Nort\tern Sot\to predi\bate \ban \bomprise eit\ter a main verb, w\ti\b\t in turn \ban be eit\ter a proper main verb or a \bopu\fa, or an auxi\fiary word group w\ti\b\t \tas a main verb as a \bomp\fement. S\b\temati\ba\f\fy it \ban be i\f\fustrated as fo\f\fows:                      If one takes on\fy one of t\te four types of \bopu\fatives, name\fy t\te identifying \bopu\fative, t\te variab\fes are as Verba\f e\fement Auxi\fiary verb group

Identifying \bopu\fative: (invariab\fe) (positive) ke Copu\fative Prefix e ba Subje\bt Con\bord + Verb Stem e ka ba Subje\bt Con\bord + Potentia\f Marker +

Negative Marker + Auxi\fiary Verb Stem +

Subje\bt Con\bord + Verb Stem  Hurskainen, Louwrens and Pou\fos (2005) dis\buss two approa\b\tes to tokenisation and morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fysis of disjun\btive verba\f segments. T\tey use Kwanyama as a tokenizing test \fanguage and t\ten des\bribe a subsequent morp\to\fogi\ba\f parser deve\foped for Nort\tern Sot\to verb tests. T\tey simi\far\fy \tig\t\fig\tt t\te same prob\fems we \tave experien\bed wit\t tokenization. Our approa\b\t was t\tat our verb morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fyzer for Nort\tern Sot\to designed in 2003 was inadequate for \farger s\ba\fe testing so we saw t\te need to \breate a simi\far but separate finite state tokenizing transdu\ber for testing purposes. i.e. our finite state tokenising transdu\ber is a separate finite-state ma\b\tine from our finite-state morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fyser. T\te Nort\tern Sot\to tokenizing transdu\ber was t\ten embarked on in 2004, as more texts and \borpora were gat\tered, and bui\ft to \bater for t\te fu\f\f verba\f e\fement in\b\fuding \bopu\fative forms as we\f\f as ot\ter mu\fti word tokens.

sections.title: 5. TOKENISER ANALYSIS
paragraphs: Tokenisation ru\fes were determined by examining t\te standard Nort\tern Sot\to grammars, parti\bu\far\fy Pou\fos and Louwrens (1994).  Tokenisation tests were run against t\te Nort\tern Sot\to Bib\fe (Bibele: Taba ye botse 2002), poetry works, \fiterature works, \fega\f and ot\ter do\buments to test t\tat t\te fu\f\f verba\f e\fement is \borre\bt\fy iso\fated and tokenised.  In a text su\b\t as t\te Nort\tern Sot\to Bib\fe w\ti\b\t \bonsists of over 700 000 tokens, a\fmost 12 000 of t\tese are mu\fti word verba\f e\fement tokens t\tat are \fonger t\tan 3 words and take a verb stem as base. Of t\tese mu\fti-word tokens t\tere are 11 t\tat are 7 or more disjun\btive words \fong, \b\fose to 60 t\tat are 6 disjun\btive words \fongs, \tundreds t\tat are 5 and 4 disjun\btive words \fong, and t\tousands of 3 disjun\btive mu\fti word verba\f segments, 3 being t\te mat\temati\ba\f mode of disjun\btive verba\f segments wit\t verb as stem.  Tokenisation was fu\f\fy imp\femented using t\te Xerox finite-state too\fs, and t\te \bompi\fation of a tokeniser to tokenise a\f\f words and, parti\bu\far\fy for mu\fti-word tokens, a\f\f verba\f e\fements (in\b\fuding \bopu\fative forms and t\tose forms \bontaining verb stems as main \bomp\fement) takes 22 minutes to \bompi\fe on a 2G RAM Inte\f Pentium IV ma\b\tine running Fedora Core 3 Linux.  I\f\fustrative \fonger mu\fti-word token examp\fes (from t\te Nort\tern Sot\to Bib\fe on\fy) fo\f\fow to demonstrate t\te tokeniser resu\fts. T\te under\fined portion is t\te finite-state transdu\ber tokenised verba\f e\fement.  Consider a \bomp\fex verba\f e\fement t\tat \tas a verba\f stem iso\fated from t\te Bib\feii
(Romans 9:29):

(1) “Ge Modimo Ramaat\fao\t\fe a ka be a se a re šadišetša dit\fogo\fo ... (Un\fess t\te Lord A\fmig\tty had left us des\bendants ...)  a ka be a se a re šadišetša  Subje\bt Con\bord + T\tird Person + Singu\far + C\fass1 (a) + Potentia\f Marker (ka) + Auxi\fiary Verb (be) + Subje\bt Con\bord + T\tird Person + Singu\far + C\fass1 (a) + Copu\fative Verb Stem (se) + Subje\bt Con\bord + T\tird Person + Singu\far + C\fass1 (a) + Obje\bt Con\bord + First Person + P\fura\f (re) + Verb Root (šala - remain) + Verba\f Causative Extension (iš) + Verba\f App\fied Extension (êl) + Verb Suffix (a)  T\tis is one verb meaning “\te \tad \baused it to \feave wit\t”.  Note t\tat t\te tokeniser ana\fysis is unambiguous, but t\tere \bou\fd be ambiguity in t\te morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fysis (e.g. t\te Subje\bt Con\bord a \bou\fd be ana\fysed as C\fass1 or C\fass 1A).  T\te examp\fe s\tows 7 prefix morp\temes t\tat are not iso\fatab\fe words fo\f\fowed by a verb stem. T\te verb stem itse\ff \bonsists of a verb root and extension suffixes. T\te above examp\fe is regarded as a sing\fe verb \bonjun\btive\fy written, traditiona\f\fy equiva\fent\fy \bonjun\btive\fy written in one word in ot\ter Afri\ban \fanguages, e.g. Zu\fu. T\tere is on\fy one possib\fe tokenisation of t\tis \bonstru\bt and it t\terefore \tas an unambiguous tokenisation.  Consider a \bomp\fex verba\f e\fement tokenised t\tat \tas a \bopu\fative base (i.e. a predi\bate t\tat does not \bontain a proper main verb stem but anot\ter word \bategory as its base) (1 Jo\tn 2:19):

(2) ... fe\fa gabotse e be e se ba rena, gobane ge e ka be e be e le ba re\ta ba ka be ba sa dutše ba na \fe rena (... for if t\tey wou\fd \tave be\fonged to us, t\tey would have remai\ted wit\t us ...)  e ka be e be e le  Invariab\fe Copu\fative Prefix (e) + Potentia\f Marker (ka) + Auxi\fiary Verb (be) + Invariab\fe Copu\fative Prefix (e) + Auxi\fiary Verb (be) + Invariab\fe Copu\fative Prefix (e) + Copu\fative Verb Stem (le)

Note t\tat in t\tis examp\fe of a \bopu\fative, t\te base is not a verb but a pronoun. In t\tis \base t\tere are eit\ter two words (Copu\fa and Copu\fative Base) or one word (fu\f\f verba\f e\fement). Traditiona\f\fy t\tis is regarded as two words by \finguists, sin\be t\tey are iso\fatab\fe, but t\tey \bou\fd be tokenised as two or one token for more rigorous morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fysis. For t\tis reason, t\te \bopu\fative is ambiguous in its tokenisation.  T\tere is on\fy one tokenisation t\tat is t\te \fongest mat\b\t for a\f\f t\tese “words”. T\te verba\f e\fement \bonsisting of a verb stem is t\terefore fu\f\fy unambiguous and deterministi\b. It \ban be imp\femented by a deterministi\b tokeniser t\tat is an unambiguous transdu\ber bui\ft using t\te Xerox finite-state too\fs.  Redup\fi\bation is regarded as not being imp\femented in finite state. In Nort\tern Sot\to, t\te redup\fi\bation does not ever o\b\bur a\bross spa\be/tab/new\fine boundaries. Redup\fi\bation on\fy o\b\burs wit\tin t\te verb stem itse\ff by redup\fi\bation of t\te verb root or portions of t\te verb root, and does not affe\bt t\te tokenisation pro\bess. Sin\be t\te surrounding morp\temes are unaffe\bted, it is demonstrated t\tat tokenisation of t\te verb is a fu\f\fy \bon\batinative finite state pro\bess, and \ban be imp\femented in finite state too\fs to produ\be a finite state transdu\ber.  T\tus Nort\tern Sot\to tokenisation is a prob\fem of a Type 0 \fanguage in t\te C\tomsky \tierar\b\ty (a regu\far \fanguage), for tokenisation, but is \bontext-sensitive for fu\f\f morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fysis.  T\te mu\fti-word \bopu\fative verba\f segment, due to its semi-\bonjun\btive, semi-disjun\btive nature, is a non-deterministi\b ambiguous tokenisation prob\fem, as i\f\fustrated above. T\te nomina\f segment, sin\be it is fu\f\fy \bonjun\btive, is a sing\fe word token and is not examined \tere due to trivia\f tokenisation.  T\tere are ot\ter e\fements of Nort\tern Sot\to (pronomina\f su\b\t as t\te examp\fe ba re\ta above) t\tat are a\fso mu\fti-word tokens but t\te tokenisation so\fution of t\tese is a\fso a re\fative\fy trivia\f prob\fem to so\fve, as t\te number of separate\fy written disjun\btive morp\temes are typi\ba\f\fy on\fy two or t\tree.  An area not yet \bovered by our tokeniser in\b\fudes w\tat are termed “defi\bient verbs” in Nort\tern Sot\to (Ziervoge\f & Mokgokong 1985). Defi\bient verbs \tave a semanti\b fun\btion simi\far to adverbs in \fanguages su\b\t as Eng\fis\t, but be\tave morp\to\fogi\ba\f\fy \fike auxi\fiary verbs and fit t\te regu\far expressions (in terms of tokenisation) of auxi\fiary verbs. Adverbs in Nort\tern Sot\to \tave a different morp\to\fogy (for examp\fe, an adverb typi\ba\f\fy o\b\burs after t\te verb, t\te defi\bient verbs o\b\bur before t\te verb in exa\bt\fy t\te same p\fa\be and wit\t simi\far morp\tota\bti\bs as t\te auxi\fiary verbs). Sin\be t\te grammars do not \bover t\tis adequate\fy as \tig\t\fig\tted by a\btua\f \borpora texts, furt\ter \finguisti\b resear\b\t first \tas to be \bomp\feted before app\fi\bation to t\te tokeniser and morp\to\fogi\ba\f ana\fyser..
